questions.question: Which of the following is a unit of length?
questions.explanation: The meter (m) is the SI unit of length.

questions.question: Which tool do you use to measure mass at home?
questions.explanation: A kitchen scale measures mass in grams or kilograms.

questions.question: Time is measured in seconds (s).
questions.explanation: Seconds are the base unit for measuring time.

questions.question: Name the basic unit used to measure temperature in everyday life in Italy.
questions.explanation: We commonly measure temperature in degrees Celsius (°C).

questions.question: What do we call quantities like length, mass, time, and temperature?
questions.explanation: These are basic physical quantities that describe the world.

questions.question: Matter is anything that has mass and takes up space.
questions.explanation: Objects, liquids, and gases all have mass and volume.

questions.question: Which of these is NOT made of matter?
questions.explanation: Light is energy, not matter.

questions.question: What tiny building blocks make up all matter?
questions.explanation: All matter is made of very small particles (atoms and molecules).

questions.question: Which list shows a solid, a liquid, and a gas?
questions.explanation: Brick is solid, milk is liquid, oxygen is gas.

questions.question: Energy and matter are exactly the same thing.
questions.explanation: Matter has mass and volume; energy is the ability to do work or cause change.

questions.question: Which material is usually the lightest for a water bottle?
questions.explanation: Plastic bottles are common because plastic is light and cheap.

questions.question: Wood is a natural material.
questions.explanation: Wood comes directly from trees.

questions.question: Which material is usually best for electrical wires?
questions.explanation: Copper is a good electrical conductor.

questions.question: Name one hard material often used for windows.
questions.explanation: Glass is hard and transparent, so it is used for windows.

questions.question: Plastic and metal feel the same temperature when you touch them.
questions.explanation: Metal conducts heat better, so it often feels colder or hotter than plastic.

questions.question: Which instrument do you use to measure temperature?
questions.explanation: A thermometer measures temperature in degrees Celsius.

questions.question: Repeating a measurement helps you see possible errors.
questions.explanation: Taking several measurements shows if your values are consistent.

questions.question: Which instrument measures mass?
questions.explanation: A balance or scale measures mass.

questions.question: If a ruler has marks every millimeter, what is the smallest division you can read?
questions.explanation: The smallest division is 1 mm when marks are that close.

questions.question: What happens when ice melts?
questions.explanation: Melting is the change from solid to liquid.

questions.question: Evaporation is when a liquid turns into a gas.
questions.explanation: Heating water can make it evaporate into water vapor.

questions.question: Name the state of matter of water vapor.
questions.explanation: Water vapor is water in the gas state.

questions.question: Condensation happens when:
questions.explanation: Condensation is when a gas cools and becomes liquid.

questions.question: Glass is usually more fragile than wood.
questions.explanation: Glass breaks more easily when hit compared to wood.

questions.question: Which material is a good thermal conductor?
questions.explanation: Metals like copper conduct heat well.

questions.question: If a material returns to its shape after bending, which property is it showing?
questions.explanation: Elasticity means the material can flex and then return to its original shape.

questions.question: A brittle material breaks easily without bending much.
questions.explanation: Fragility or brittleness means little deformation before breaking.
